Planets.Name: Earth

Location.QuadrantNotes: Earth is the human homeworld and the seat of major Federation institutions.

PrimaryLanguageNotes: Federation Standard is widely used; most visitors will not have communication issues.

Planets.TravelSummary: Earth is the homeworld of humanity and the political heart of the United Federation of Planets. It is home to Starfleet Headquarters in San Francisco and remains a major diplomatic, cultural, and historical center.

Appearance.GeneralLook: A blue-white world dominated by oceans, varied continents, and dynamic cloud systems, with major metropolitan regions alongside protected natural reserves.
FromOrbit: High-density orbital traffic and infrastructure during major Starfleet periods
Major approach lanes into the Sol system and Earth orbit are tightly controlled during alerts
NotableLandscapes: San Francisco Bay area and coastline
European river valleys and historic urban cores
Rural preserves and heritage sites tied to First Contact history
SurfaceNotes: Civic architecture ranges from preserved pre-warp landmarks to sleek Federation-era public buildings.
Many locations prominently integrate water features, parks, and pedestrian spaces.

NotableCultures.Name: United Earth civic culture
NotableCultures.Notes: Visitors will find strong norms around pluralism, diplomacy, and public education.

NotableCultures.Name: Starfleet community presence
NotableCultures.Notes: Academy cadets, officers, and visiting crews shape local rhythms near major facilities.

VisitorEtiquette: Expect security screening and identity checks near Starfleet and Federation facilities.
Avoid restricted shoreline and airspace zones around major orbital-interface sites during alerts.
Respect memorials and historic sites—many are treated as solemn civic spaces.
Food culture is wide-ranging; reservations are common for renowned family restaurants.

Weather.ClimateType: Wide-ranging climates and seasons across continents, from polar to tropical.
Weather.Seasonality: Seasonal variation depends on region; many areas experience distinct seasonal cycles.

Hazards.Notes: Local storms can delay shuttle schedules and outdoor events; buffer time is recommended.
During major political or military events, travel corridors may change rapidly.

TopAttractions.Name: Starfleet/Federation civic district (San Francisco)
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Frequently Federation/Starfleet hub with recognizable waterfront setting.

Activities: Museum and archive days (Federation history, warp-era exhibits)
Bayfront walks and scenic transit loops
Cuisine trips spanning regional Earth traditions
Seasonal festivals and cultural performances
Restrictions: No-fly / no-drone zones near Starfleet and Federation executive areas during high security.
Certain Academy areas are cadet-only and may be closed during training and examinations.
SafetyNotes: Check current advisories for Sol system traffic controls before arrival.
Carry ID and travel authorization if planning visits near major government campuses.
During major anniversaries and ceremonies, crowds can be dense—plan transit accordingly.

Entry: Federation standard customs procedures (varies by era and political context).
Visitors approaching through Earth orbit may be routed via controlled corridors, especially during alerts.
LocalTransport: High-capacity urban transit networks in major cities
Shuttles and licensed air/space traffic near orbital-interface zones
Transporter use depends on local infrastructure and security rules
CurrencyNotes: Visitors should expect largely cashless exchange; carry travel credentials compatible with local services.
Lodging: City-center hotels and guest facilities near major cultural districts
Outlying eco-lodges and heritage inns near historic sites
Communications: Dense communications infrastructure; universal translator support is generally unnecessary for Standard speech, but available for visitors.

Planets.Name: Vulcan

Location.QuadrantNotes: Vulcan is a core Federation member world associated with early Federation history.
Location.Region: United Federation of Planets (member world; later Ni'Var)

SkyNotes: Vulcan has no natural moons in canon references; it forms a binary pair with the companion planet T'Khut, which can be prominent in the sky under clear conditions.

LocalTimekeeping.TimeFormat: Local standards; visitors commonly rely on shipboard chronometers and civic time beacons.

Planets.TravelSummary: Vulcan is the homeworld of the Vulcan people and an early member of the Federation. It is known for arid landscapes, rigorous cultural traditions, and prominent ceremonial and governmental sites.

Appearance.GeneralLook: Predominantly arid terrain with deserts and rocky plains, punctuated by settlements and ceremonial locations.
FromOrbit: Desert belts and highland contours are visually dominant
The Vulcan system’s companion world relationships are a notable feature of local cartography
NotableLandscapes: Vulcan's Forge (desert/volcanic badlands)
Sacred mountain sites (e.g., Mount Seleya)
Desert-edge urban corridors (e.g., ShiKahr region)
SurfaceNotes: Visitors commonly report intense light, rapid dehydration risk, and strong day–night comfort swings.
Some wilderness zones can interfere with technology and require analog navigation backups.

Cities.Name: ShiKahr
Cities.Role: Major city near the edge of the Forge
Highlights: Desert-edge architecture optimized for shade and heat control
Cultural residences associated with prominent Vulcan families in some eras
Cities.LocalVibe: Orderly, quiet, and tradition-forward; visitors are expected to be self-contained and respectful.

Cities.Name: Gol
Highlights: Referenced in Vulcan historical accounts and cautionary tales
Often approached as an educational stop rather than a leisure destination
Cities.LocalVibe: Austere heritage site—visit via curator-led routes if available.

NotableCultures.Name: Surakian tradition
NotableCultures.Notes: Pilgrimage, scholarship, and meditation are central to many visitor experiences.

NotableCultures.Name: Scientific institutions
NotableCultures.Notes: Academic culture is prominent; lectures and symposiums can be major tourist draws in some eras.

VisitorEtiquette: Keep your voice low; emotional displays are often considered disruptive in public spaces.
Avoid unsolicited physical contact; ask permission before assisting someone physically.
Never attempt or request a mind meld casually—consent and cultural context are critical.
Dress for sun and dust: breathable layers, eye protection, and sealed footwear are standard.
Carry water and electrolyte supplementation for outdoor travel; dehydration can escalate quickly.
Follow shrine and sanctuary rules precisely: silence zones, footwear policies, and restricted steps are common.
Do not treat sacred symbols (e.g., IDIC iconography) as casual merchandise in solemn spaces.
When invited into a home, wait for explicit guidance on seating, food, and conversation topics.
Photography/recording may be restricted in religious and academic areas—ask before capturing images.
On guided treks, stay with your group; terrain and stormfronts can shift quickly.

Weather.ClimateType: Hot and arid in many regions.
Weather.Seasonality: Seasonal detail varies by region; heat and low humidity are common baseline conditions.

Hazards.Notes: Fast-moving storms with blinding sand and lightning-like electrical discharges; can last hours to days and require sealed shelter.
Can interfere with scanners, communicators, and transporters (especially in 22nd-century tech contexts).
Primary day-trip risk for offworld visitors; plan shade breaks and carry water beyond Earth-normal expectations.

TopAttractions.Name: Cultural and ceremonial sites (visit via approved protocols)
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Vulcan culture and rituals are central to many stories; access is portrayed as formal.

Activities: Guided desert treks (non-Forge routes recommended for casual visitors)
Museum and archive visits focused on Vulcan history and philosophy
Meditation retreats and cultural workshops (by invitation or registration)
Night-sky viewing when conditions allow (companion planet visibility can be striking)
Restrictions: Forge-area travel may require permits, guides, and approved equipment checklists.
Sacred and governmental facilities may restrict offworld visitors during political tension or ceremonial periods.
Some rites and trials are not tourist events; do not attempt participation without formal invitation.
SafetyNotes: Never enter the Forge without sealed shelter options and a guide familiar with storm behavior.
Carry redundant navigation and communications options; some terrain can disrupt instruments.
Plan arrivals and departures around heat peaks; dawn/dusk itineraries reduce risk.
Respect local authority immediately during advisories—Vulcan enforcement is typically strict and procedural.

Entry: Expect strict customs and documentation checks; Vulcan authorities prioritize order and clarity.
Visitors may be required to declare scientific equipment, recording devices, and medical supplies.
LocalTransport: Urban transit and regulated shuttles near major cities
Licensed ground vehicles for desert routes
Guided convoys for wilderness itineraries in higher-risk regions
CurrencyNotes: Visitors should plan for credential-based payment systems and pre-authorized travel accounts.
Lodging: Quiet guest facilities with strong privacy norms near cities
Retreat-style accommodations for meditation and study travelers
Communications: Universal translator is useful for cultural nuance, but many Vulcans are fluent in Federation Standard in Federation-era contexts.

Planets.Name: Ferenginar

Location.QuadrantNotes: Ferenginar is located in Ferengi space in the Alpha Quadrant; no consistent sector label is established in primary canon.

PrimaryLanguageNotes: Ferengi language is common in domestic contexts; Federation Standard is widely understood in trade-facing areas.

LocalTimekeeping.TimeFormat: Local standards; visitors typically rely on shipboard chronometers and civic time beacons for appointments.

Planets.TravelSummary: Ferenginar is the homeworld of the Ferengi and a major center of Ferengi commerce and government. The planet is known for frequent rainfall and heavy humidity.

Appearance.GeneralLook: Overcast skies and persistent rain are common, with wet streets and covered market spaces in urban districts.
FromOrbit: Persistent cloud cover and broad weather systems are common
Approach traffic concentrates around major commercial hubs and government districts
NotableLandscapes: Lowland wetlands and swampy basins
River channels and drainage corridors carrying heavy runoff
Dense urban districts clustered around major marketplaces
SurfaceNotes: Expect wet ground conditions almost everywhere—non-slip footwear and sealed bags are standard.
Many high-traffic civic areas are covered or partially enclosed to keep commerce moving during downpours.

NotableCultures.Name: Rules of Acquisition civic culture
NotableCultures.Notes: Business norms and social etiquette are often framed through the Rules of Acquisition and the pursuit of profit.

NotableCultures.Name: Ferengi Commerce Authority presence
NotableCultures.Notes: Regulatory enforcement exists alongside widespread graft and aggressive sales tactics; visitors should stick to reputable vendors.

VisitorEtiquette: Assume every price is negotiable unless explicitly posted as fixed—haggling is expected in many contexts.
Get agreements in writing (or recorded contract form) before exchanging funds or goods—clarify fees, delivery, and refunds.
Avoid insulting someone’s business acumen; negotiations are social contests as much as transactions.
Keep personal financial details private; targeted upselling and ‘exclusive’ offers are common.
Respect local laws and social norms, including gender and dress restrictions in specific venues—do not assume offworld norms apply.
Be cautious with gifts and ‘samples’—confirm whether they’re free before accepting.

Weather.ClimateType: Humid climate with frequent, heavy rainfall.
Weather.Seasonality: Rain is described as persistent and pervasive; local weather variation is more about intensity and storm bursts than clear dry seasons.

Hazards.Notes: Sudden downpours can flood low streets and disrupt surface travel; plan sheltered routes and flexible timing.
Electronics, paper goods, and clothing can degrade quickly without sealing and drying routines.
Polished stone, metal walkways, and market tiles can be slick; non-slip footwear is strongly recommended.

TravelGear: Sealed outer layer or poncho; quick-dry clothing
Waterproof bags for comm devices and padds
Anti-fog eye protection in heavy humidity

TopAttractions.Name: Tower of Commerce (exterior / authorized areas)
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Iconic seat of Ferengi leadership and a recognizable skyline feature.

Activities: Market crawls with a vetted guide (price-checking and safe vendor lists)
Cultural lectures on the Rules of Acquisition and Ferengi economic history
Museum days (trade, gambling, negotiation exhibits)
Food and beverage tastings with humidity-resistant packaging
Restrictions: Government and FCA areas in the Tower of Commerce may be closed without notice during investigations or political shifts.
Some venues enforce local social norms strictly; verify dress and conduct rules before arrival.
SafetyNotes: Avoid ‘too-good-to-be-true’ offers—use licensed vendors and confirm authentication for high-value items.
Do not carry all funds or latinum in one place; use secure accounts and incremental transfers.
If a deal becomes pressured or time-limited, walk away—high-pressure tactics are common in tourist zones.

Entry: Expect customs declarations focused on trade goods, valuables, and commercial equipment.
Business-visas or transaction permits may be required for high-value buying/selling depending on era and local policy.
LocalTransport: Covered pedestrian corridors within major market districts
Licensed ground transport and shuttle links between civic zones
Transit routes may reroute around flooded streets during heavy rain bursts
CurrencyNotes: Latinums and contract-based credit arrangements are common in Ferengi trade contexts; confirm exchange and fee schedules in writing.
Lodging: Business hotels and guest houses near major market hubs
Humidity-managed suites (recommended for visitors with sensitive equipment or attire)
Communications: Universal translator is helpful for negotiations and contract nuance; consider using verified legal translation services for major purchases.

MajorCities: (Capital) — commonly treated as the seat of the Grand Nagus’ government
PointsOfInterest: Great Marketplace / Sacred Marketplace (public commerce district)

Planets.Name: Risa

Location.QuadrantNotes: Risa’s quadrant placement varies across cartography and reference works; recent star charts and summaries commonly place it in the Beta Quadrant.
Location.StarSystem: Epsilon Ceti star system (Epsilon Ceti B)
Location.Region: United Federation of Planets (member world; major tourism destination)

PrimaryLanguageNotes: Federation Standard is widely used in tourism districts; local language and customs remain prominent in cultural settings.

LocalTimekeeping.TimeFormat: Local standards; resort schedules and Starfleet visitors commonly operate on shipboard chronometers.

Planets.TravelSummary: Risa is a Federation resort world renowned for leisure culture and climate control systems designed to maintain comfortable conditions for visitors.

Appearance.GeneralLook: Tropical coasts, lagoons, resort architecture, and landscaped gardens are characteristic of the main visitor zones.
FromOrbit: Bright ocean expanses with frequent cloud bands
Approach routes are dense during peak travel seasons
Tourism hubs produce distinctive night-side illumination clusters around resort belts
NotableLandscapes: White-sand beaches and shallow coastal shelves
Warm lagoons and reef-like shallows near resort districts
Garden complexes and landscaped courtyards integrated into hotels and villas
SurfaceNotes: Public spaces prioritize walkability: covered paths, misting arches, and shaded plazas.
Dress norms are relaxed in resort zones, but guests should still respect posted rules for sacred/cultural sites.

Cities.Name: Resort Belt (capital tourism district)
Cities.Role: Primary visitor zone and hospitality core
Highlights: High-capacity transit loops and concierge hubs
Cities.LocalVibe: Festive, relaxed, flirtatious, and service-forward—designed to make visitors forget they’re on a schedule.

NotableCultures.Name: Hospitality guild culture
NotableCultures.Notes: Tourism work is highly respected; many services are ritualized into ‘experiences’ rather than simple transactions.

NotableCultures.Name: Jamaharon tradition (symbolic courtship custom)
NotableCultures.Notes: Often referenced through the horga'hn statuette; treated playfully in resort zones but still grounded in local etiquette.

VisitorEtiquette: Consent-first: flirting is common, but never assume interest; follow clear verbal or behavioral cues.
If you accept an invitation, clarify expectations—Risians often treat communication as part of the experience.
Respect local symbols (including the horga'hn) and avoid using them to embarrass others.
Dress norms are relaxed, but resorts still post rules for dining, ceremonies, and formal events—follow them.
Don’t mock leisure culture; on Risa, relaxation is treated as a serious civic priority.

Weather.ClimateType: Warm, stabilized weather maintained by planetary climate systems.
Weather.Seasonality: Conditions are intentionally moderated; seasonal extremes are minimal in resort regions.
TravelGear: Light breathable clothing plus one dry layer for sudden storms
Comfort footwear for long promenade walks
Weather.Summary: Tropical ‘paradise’ conditions are largely engineered: Risa’s weather control system is used to maintain consistently pleasant temperatures, breezes, and skies for visitors.

TopAttractions.Name: Beach and resort stay
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Core depiction: leisure, warm water, and resort culture.

TopAttractions.Name: Horga'hn custom (cultural symbol)
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Recurring element associated with Risian romance culture.

Activities: Beach and lagoon swimming
Sailing and small-craft excursions (conditions permitting)
Resort spa circuits and wellness programs
Nightlife: clubs, live music, and themed social events
Guided cultural tours focusing on Risian customs and hospitality traditions
Restrictions: Weather control and planetary infrastructure sites are restricted.
Some events have explicit participation rules; resorts may enforce conduct standards tightly to protect guests.
SafetyNotes: Use official booking channels—tourist zones can attract opportunistic scams and counterfeit ‘exclusive’ passes.
If storms hit, leave the water immediately and follow resort shelter instructions.
Set boundaries clearly; if someone ignores them, contact resort security—Risa prioritizes guest safety and consent.

Entry: Federation-friendly arrival procedures; peak seasons can produce heavy traffic and longer berth allocation times.
Resorts often handle customs/registration through pre-arrival concierge workflows.
LocalTransport: Resort transit loops (shuttles, trams, and pedestrian corridors)
Licensed watercraft and charter excursions
Transporter use varies by venue and local security posture
CurrencyNotes: Resort packages and Federation-standard payments are common; confirm what’s included vs. premium add-ons before arrival.
Lodging: Lagoon resorts, beach hotels, and private villas
Quiet retreat properties away from main nightlife zones
Communications: Excellent tourism communications coverage; most visitors operate comfortably in Federation Standard with translator support for nuance.

Key.SeriesOrFilm: DS9: Let He Who Is Without Sin...
ENT: Two Days and Two Nights

PointsOfInterest: Resort zones and shore-leave districts (weapons prohibited)
Weather control complex (restricted; seen during sabotage events)

Planets.Name: Qo'noS

Location.QuadrantNotes: Sector label for Qo'noS is given in reference summaries and cartography; Klingon-space borders shift by era.

PrimaryLanguageNotes: Klingon (tlhIngan Hol) is dominant; Federation Standard is understood in diplomatic, trade, and offworlder-facing contexts.

LocalTimekeeping.TimeFormat: Local standards; visitors often rely on shipboard chronometers when coordinating with offworld schedules.

Planets.TravelSummary: Qo'noS (Kronos) is the Klingon homeworld and the seat of imperial politics. The First City and the Great Hall are central locations for governance and ceremony.

Appearance.GeneralLook: Rugged, austere landscapes and monumental civic architecture are central of the capital.
FromOrbit: Approach corridors are tightly managed, with traffic patterns shaped by Klingon security and military priorities
Major population centers present dense night-side illumination clusters, with heavy emphasis around the capital region
NotableLandscapes: Volcanic regions and basaltic terrain
Extensive cave systems and subterranean networks
Rugged highlands and broad plains outside major urban centers
SurfaceNotes: Many civic buildings are designed for spectacle: grand entrances, wide courtyards, and intimidating vertical scale.
Expect visible security—uniformed guards, checkpoints, and restricted zones near government sites.

NotableCultures.Name: Great House politics
NotableCultures.Notes: Major families (Houses) hold power, influence, and obligation networks; visitors should avoid casually taking sides in disputes.

NotableCultures.Name: Ritual honor culture
NotableCultures.Notes: Many interactions are framed through public respect, challenge etiquette, and visible confidence—ambiguity can be read as weakness or deception.

VisitorEtiquette: Use correct titles and names; show respect for rank and House affiliation when it is declared.
Be direct and keep promises—backing out of agreements can be treated as dishonorable.
Avoid public mockery or sarcasm about Klingon tradition; it can escalate quickly.
Do not touch weapons, ceremonial objects, or House insignia without permission.
Follow checkpoint instructions immediately; arguing with guards is a fast way to end your trip.
If invited to a ritual or ceremony, ask a local liaison about expected conduct beforehand.

Weather.Seasonality: Seasonality depends on region; travel conditions can change quickly with local weather.

Conditions: Overcast or green-tinged skies in some depictions

Hazards.Notes: Political events can lock down transit corridors and public squares with little notice; keep alternate routes and shelter options.
Avoid unescorted travel near vents, unstable rock, and restricted cavern systems.
In late-23rd-century contexts, the Praxis disaster created planet-wide environmental strain and heightened controls.

TravelGear: A formal outfit if attending civic events (as advised by your liaison)

TopAttractions.Name: Great Hall (authorized access)
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Central location for Klingon ceremony and High Council politics.

Activities: Guided city walks in authorized districts
Ceremony observation (when permitted)
Curated cultural briefings with a local liaison
Supervised excursions to geological viewpoints away from restricted zones
Restrictions: Government buildings and High Council-adjacent areas are frequently restricted to authorized visitors.
Security conditions can change rapidly based on House politics or imperial events.
SafetyNotes: Travel with a vetted liaison if you plan to visit civic centers—this is not a casual walk-up destination.
Avoid bartering with unauthorized agents offering 'Council access' or 'House introductions'.
If challenged or provoked, disengage and leave—do not escalate without local guidance.

Entry: Entry requirements vary with the Klingon Empire’s diplomatic posture; visitors may need sponsorship, permits, or escort arrangements.
Expect strict inspections for weapons, recording equipment, and contraband.
LocalTransport: Guarded transit corridors and checkpointed routes in capital districts
Ground transport and shuttle links between authorized zones
Access restrictions are common near ceremonial sites and government compounds
CurrencyNotes: Trade rules depend on era and local policy; confirm what exchanges are permitted before arrival.
Lodging: Guest quarters in authorized districts (often arranged through sponsors)
Communications: Translator support is strongly recommended for formal proceedings and legal terms; direct language is culturally preferred.

Key.SeriesOrFilm: Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country (Praxis disaster context)

PointsOfInterest: Klingon High Council chamber (in the Great Hall)

Planets.Name: Andoria

Location.QuadrantNotes: Andoria (also known as Andor) is the Andorian homeworld and a core Federation member world in later eras.

PrimaryLanguageNotes: Andorian is common in domestic settings; Federation Standard is widely used in government, trade, and offworlder-facing contexts.

LocalTimekeeping.TimeFormat: Local standards; visitors commonly coordinate via shipboard chronometers for tours and transport windows.

Planets.TravelSummary: Andoria is the Andorian homeworld, an ice-dominant world of glaciers and severe cold. It is notable for Andorian culture and for its role as a major Federation member world in later eras.

Appearance.GeneralLook: Bright ice fields, glaciers, and stormy skies dominate; many facilities and settlements are built for extreme cold.
FromOrbit: Large reflective ice sheets dominate the surface coloration
Storm bands and polar cloud systems are common
Night-side illumination clusters concentrate around major cities and protected corridors
NotableLandscapes: Polar ice caps and continent-scale glaciers
Jagged mountain ridges and frozen highlands
Cracked sea-ice plates and frozen coastal shelves
SurfaceNotes: Most public infrastructure assumes freezing temperatures—expect enclosed walkways, sealed transport, and strict safety protocols.
Visibility can shift rapidly with blowing snow and low cloud ceilings.

Cities.Name: Capital city (primary civic hub)
Highlights: Insulated transit corridors connecting key districts
Cities.LocalVibe: Orderly and formal, with a strong sense of public duty; visitors are welcomed when respectful but are expected to follow rules precisely.

NotableCultures.Name: Service-forward civic tradition
NotableCultures.Notes: Government, defense, and public duty are culturally prominent; visitors should expect a more formal tone than on leisure worlds.

VisitorEtiquette: Dress for the environment and for formality—arriving underprepared is viewed as careless.
Be direct and honest; evasive answers can be interpreted as disrespect or concealment.
Ask before photographing people, ceremonies, or security infrastructure—many locations have strict restrictions.
Respect Aenar privacy rules and any restricted-zone boundaries without debate.
Follow local safety instructions in storms without improvisation.

Weather.ClimateType: Severe cold with frequent wind and snow.
Weather.Seasonality: High-latitude seasonality can produce large daylight shifts and extended storm cycles in some regions.

Hazards.Notes: Visibility can drop to near-zero quickly; guided routes and locator beacons are standard outside city limits.
Frostbite risk rises quickly in exposed zones—use layered thermal protection and adhere to time limits outdoors.
Marked corridors exist near tourist viewpoints; do not deviate from approved paths.

TravelGear: Thermal layers with windproof outer shell

TopAttractions.Name: Guided icefield vistas (where permitted)
TopAttractions.WhyGo: The ice-world environment is Andoria’s defining feature.

Activities: Guided icefield excursions with safety beacons
Aurora viewing in clear polar nights (seasonal)
Indoor cultural events and formal receptions (by invitation/permit)
Cuisine tastings suited to cold climates (warm broths, spiced dishes, hot beverages)
Restrictions: Many government and security-adjacent areas require permits or sponsorship.
Aenar regions are culturally protected and typically not open to casual tourism.
Storm alerts can close surface travel rapidly.
SafetyNotes: Do not attempt independent wilderness travel—use licensed guides and keep to marked corridors.
Carry verified shelter locations and transport fallback routes in case of closures.
Respect local security procedures; delays at checkpoints are normal and not negotiable.

Entry: Federation-friendly for most visitors, but permit requirements can increase during political or security events.
Expect safety briefings for any excursion beyond protected urban districts.
LocalTransport: Enclosed ground transit, heated corridors, and shuttle links between districts
Weather-related reroutes and temporary closures are common during storms
CurrencyNotes: Federation-standard payments are common in visitor districts; confirm excursion and gear rental inclusions in advance.
Lodging: Insulated hotels and guest quarters within protected districts
Expedition lodging for guided multi-day tours (seasonal and tightly regulated)
Communications: Strong urban coverage; out-of-city travel should include locator services and emergency beacons as standard.

Planets.Name: Bajor

Location.QuadrantNotes: Bajor is explicitly placed in the Bajor sector of the Alpha Quadrant in reference summaries.

PrimaryLanguageNotes: Bajoran is common in domestic settings; Federation Standard is widely used in government, trade, and offworld-facing contexts.

LocalTimekeeping.TimeFormat: Local standards; visitors often coordinate with Deep Space 9 schedules and shipboard chronometers.

Planets.TravelSummary: Bajor is the Bajoran homeworld, a fertile world of river valleys and mountain provinces. Bajoran society is closely tied to the Prophets-centered faith and the planet’s recovery after the Cardassian Occupation. The Bajoran wormhole lies nearby in the Denorios Belt.

Appearance.GeneralLook: Green valleys, terraced hillsides, rivers, and warm-toned stone architecture are common across provinces and cities.
FromOrbit: Broad green landmasses and deep-blue seas with visible weather systems
Dense illumination clusters around major population centers and reconstruction corridors
NotableLandscapes: Mountain valleys and river deltas
Agricultural provinces and terraced farmlands
Coastal belts and inland seas
Cave and canyon systems associated with religious myth and history
SurfaceNotes: Rural regions can feel timeless and pastoral, while urban districts show visible modernization after the Occupation.
Travel between provinces is common for pilgrimages and memorial visits; many routes have cultural significance.

NotableCultures.Name: Prophets-centered faith
NotableCultures.Notes: Religion is embedded in public life: shrines, monasteries, and ceremonies are common, and visitors are expected to show respect even when not participating.

NotableCultures.Name: Post-Occupation civic identity
NotableCultures.Notes: Memorial culture and political vigilance remain strong; certain topics are sensitive, especially in public or around veterans.

VisitorEtiquette: Treat shrines, monasteries, and religious symbols with respect—ask before photographing ceremonies or sacred objects.
Avoid casually debating Occupation history with strangers; many families are directly affected.
When invited into a religious space, follow host instructions on dress, voice level, and where to stand.
Use official guides for archaeological sites—Bajor values preservation and controls access to fragile ruins.
Be mindful of local politics: rallies, assemblies, and security shifts can occur around major events.

Weather.ClimateType: Regionally variable Class-M climate, ranging from temperate valleys to cooler mountain provinces.
Weather.Seasonality: Seasonal shifts are noticeable by province, with wetter periods in valleys and coastal belts and cooler conditions at altitude.

Conditions: Cloud ceilings that can drop quickly
Clear days alternating with rain bands

Hazards.Notes: Localized downpours can affect road and shuttle timing, especially in valleys.
Certain periods saw major quakes tied to wormhole instability; modern advisories may still reference vulnerable zones.

TravelGear: Light layers for warm valleys and cool ridges
Rain shell or compact poncho during wet seasons
Comfort footwear for pilgrimage routes and stone stairs
A respectful outfit for monastery visits (as advised locally)

TopAttractions.Name: Monasteries and pilgrimage sites (where open)
TopAttractions.WhyGo: Bajoran faith and sacred sites are central .

Activities: Temple and monastery visits (guided/approved)
Valley hikes and scenic overlooks (seasonal)
Cultural lectures on Bajoran history and faith (official venues)
Local food tastings (regional breads, stews, and produce-forward dishes)
Museum and memorial tours in urban districts
Restrictions: Certain religious sites restrict recording and limit non-participant access during ceremonies.
Some ruins and provinces have permit requirements to protect cultural heritage and sensitive recovery areas.
Fire Caves access is often restricted or culturally discouraged.
SafetyNotes: Use licensed guides for ruins and remote routes; some areas still contain Occupation-era hazards or unstable structures.
Respect security instructions during political events—crowd control can change quickly.
Avoid buying looted artifacts; Bajor takes cultural theft seriously.

Entry: Entry requirements vary by era and political climate; visitors may need permits for certain provinces, digs, or religious sites.
If arriving via Deep Space 9, expect coordination between station schedules and planet-side customs.
LocalTransport: Shuttles and ground vehicles connecting major cities and provinces
Guided transport for archaeology routes and remote monasteries
Weather and event-driven delays are common during storms or assemblies
CurrencyNotes: Local commerce is active but culturally regulated around sacred objects and artifacts; confirm what is legal to purchase and export.
Lodging: Urban hotels and guesthouses in the capital
Rural inns along pilgrimage routes (seasonal availability)
Communications: Good coverage in cities; rural valleys may require relay service or tour-provided comm support.

Key.SeriesOrFilm: DS9: What You Leave Behind (Fire Caves)

Planets.Name: Cardassia Prime

Location.QuadrantNotes: Cardassia Prime is placed in Cardassian space in the Alpha Quadrant; sector naming is not consistently provided in primary canon.
Nearby: ~5 light years from Bajor (system distance reference)

PrimaryLanguageNotes: Cardassian is dominant; Federation Standard is used in diplomatic and offworld-facing contexts.

LocalTimekeeping.TimeFormat: Local standards; visiting schedules are often coordinated through official itineraries and security checkpoints.

Planets.TravelSummary: Cardassia Prime is the Cardassian homeworld and the capital of the Cardassian Union. Its political institutions have included Central Command and the Detapa Council, and the planet’s fate is central to the Dominion War’s endgame.

Appearance.GeneralLook: A generally arid world with dust-toned landscapes and monumental urban architecture in major population centers.
FromOrbit: Large landmasses with muted coloration consistent with arid regions
Night-side illumination clustered around major urban centers and industrial corridors
NotableLandscapes: Arid plains and rocky highlands
Dusty basins and dry valleys
Heavily built urban and industrial corridors
SurfaceNotes: Public spaces in major cities can feel formal and surveilled; expect signage and guard presence even in civilian districts.
Outside approved visitor routes, conditions can become harsher and services sparser.

Cities.Name: Lakarian City
Cities.Role: Capital and primary visitor gateway (when open)
Highlights: Approved museums and public history venues
Cities.LocalVibe: Controlled, ceremonial, and security-forward—public spaces often feel designed for processions, surveillance, and state visibility.

NotableCultures.Name: State-and-service civic identity
NotableCultures.Notes: Public messaging and ceremony frequently highlight duty and the legitimacy of institutions; visitors should expect formal conduct norms in civic spaces.

VisitorEtiquette: Keep documentation ready; officials may request identification frequently.
Use formal address and avoid casual jokes about the state, military, or recent conflicts.
Don’t photograph guards, checkpoints, or restricted buildings unless explicitly permitted.
If invited into a family home, follow host rules—hospitality can be formal and status-conscious.
Avoid discussing Bajoran Occupation history with strangers; it is politically and personally sensitive.

Weather.ClimateType: Often characterized by heat, dry air, and dust-laden conditions in many regions.
Weather.Seasonality: Seasonal detail varies by region; heat and low humidity are common baseline conditions.

Hazards.Notes: Blowing dust can reduce visibility and irritate respiratory systems; use sealed eyewear and filtration when advised.
Dehydration risk rises quickly in open areas; carry water and follow excursion time limits.

TravelGear: Light, breathable clothing plus a sun-shielding outer layer

Activities: Guided city walks in authorized districts
Museum visits and public exhibitions (where open)
Officially hosted cultural talks and receptions (permit/sponsor dependent)
Restrictions: Government, intelligence, and military-adjacent areas are restricted.
Political conditions can close attractions and reroute tours with little notice.
SafetyNotes: Use licensed guides and official booking channels—avoid ‘access brokers’ offering restricted entry.
Follow checkpoint instructions immediately; do not argue protocol on-site.
Stay aware of advisories related to post-war reconstruction or local unrest.

Entry: Entry requirements depend heavily on diplomatic conditions; sponsorship and escorted itineraries may be required.
Expect inspections for weapons, recording equipment, and restricted materials.
LocalTransport: Checkpointed surface routes in major cities
Licensed shuttles and controlled corridors between approved zones
Reroutes and closures are common during security escalations
CurrencyNotes: Exchange and purchasing rules can vary by era and policy; confirm what transactions are permitted before arrival.
Lodging: Authorized hotels/guest quarters within controlled districts (often arranged through sponsors)
Communications: Translator support is recommended for formal notices and legal terms; expect monitoring in some districts.
